intro: Thesium gypsophiloides, commonly known as the gypsum thesium, is a flowering plant native to arid and semi-arid regions of southern Africa. It belongs to the family Xanthorrhoeaceae and is characterized by its compact, low-growing habit and succulent leaves. The plant produces small, yellowish-green flowers that are clustered in dense inflorescences, often resembling a bottlebrush. Thesium gypsophiloides is adapted to survive in harsh, dry environments, with thick leaves that store water and reduce transpiration. It is often found growing on rocky or gypsum soils, showcasing its specialized ecological niche.
